problem_statement: Find the parametric form of vector equation of a straight line passing through the point of intersection of the straight lines $\overrightarrow{r}=(\hat{i}+3 \hat{j}-\hat{k})+t(2 \hat{i}+3 \hat{j}+2 \hat{k})$ and $\displaystyle \frac{x-2}{1}=\displaystyle \frac{y-4}{2}=\displaystyle \frac{z+3}{4}$, and perpendicular to both straight lines.
overview: When given two lines and asked to find a line perpendicular to both, recognize that the cross product of their direction vectors will yield the required perpendicular vector.

step_details.explanation: $\htmlClass{light_blue_box_medium}{\textbf{Convert lines to parametric form and find intersection point}}$
expressions: $\displaystyle \frac{x - 1}{2} = \displaystyle \frac{y - 3}{3} = \displaystyle \frac{z + 1}{2} = s \quad \color{blue}{\text{(converted to symmetric form using direction vector } (2, 3, 2))}$
$(x, y, z) = (2s + 1, 3s + 3, 2s - 1) \quad \color{blue}{\text{(parametric equations from symmetric form)}}$
$(x, y, z) = (t + 2, 2t + 4, 4t - 3) \quad \color{blue}{\text{(parametric equations from symmetric form)}}$
$2s - t = 1, 3s - 2t = 1, 2s - 4t = -2 \quad \color{blue}{\text{(system of equations from coordinate equality)}}$

step_details.explanation: $\htmlClass{light_green_box_medium}{\textbf{Find direction vector perpendicular to both lines}}$
expressions: $\overrightarrow{b} \times \overrightarrow{d} = \begin{vmatrix} \hat{i} & \hat{j} & \hat{k} \\ 2 & 3 & 2 \\ 1 & 2 & 4 \end{vmatrix} = 8\hat{i} - 6\hat{j} + \hat{k} \quad \color{blue}{\text{(cross product gives vector perpendicular to both)}}$

$\overrightarrow{r} = (3\hat{i} + 6\hat{j} + \hat{k}) + m(8\hat{i} - 6\hat{j} + \hat{k}), m \in \mathbb{R} \quad \color{blue}{\text{(using intersection point from step 1 and perpendicular vector from step 2)}}$

short_cuts: Cross product of two vectors gives a vector perpendicular to both. Use this to find the direction vector of the required line.
